problem.p: A spherical ball of radius R and mass m is released from rest and slides down a frictionless slope of height h. The slope ends with a horizontal surface, which leads to a flat region with friction. The ball begins rotating when it reaches this patch, and eventually rolls without slipping. The goal is to determine the speed of the ball when it reaches the end of area 6. What is the most appropriate way to decompose this problem?

choicegroup.choice: Three problems: 1-2, the 2/3 boundary, and 3-4 (can ignore 5 and 6)

problem.p: My answer to part 1 is justified because:

choicegroup.choice: Mechanical energy is conserved in all areas in this problem.
Mechanical energy is conserved in areas without friction.
Mechanical energy is conserved in areas without friction and in areas where the ball is rolling without slipping.
When the ball moves from the frictionless slope to the flat area with friction, the transition can be modeled as a collision.
